However, she didn’t earn very much so a year ago she started to sell other products too such as toilet paper, sweets, meneitos (a local snack), soup, and other items in small quantities. Her business has already benefitted from a Kiva loan which was repaid properly and on time. Anaju now wants to buy a new oven as the one she has is in poor condition after being used for so many years. She also wants to buy more stock for her store. She would like a loan to buy an oven (US$230), two boxes of Maruchan soup ($20 per box), three quintales (100 pounds) of flour ($38 per quintal), and a carton of toilet paper ($16).

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy an oven and products for her store

loans.name: Cesar Edward

texts.es:
Cesar, tiene 18 años, es soltero y actualmente esta estudiando la carrera profesional de turismo en el instituto privado “ESITUR” y esta cursando el tercer semestre. Cesar en sus hora libres ayuda a vender artesanía en el stand de sus papas. Ya son doce años que ayuda a sus papas con la venta. Cesar va abrir un taller de confección de artesanía de tipo platería y él va proveedor de productos a sus papas. Cesar nos cuenta que el turismo ha bajado y las ventas también  debido a las precipitaciones fluviales que cayeron en la ciudad, haciendo que muchos turistas cancelen sus viajes. Cesar usará el crédito para comprar herramientas de trabajo como incrustadora, soldadora y materiales como plata. El sueño de Cesar es terminar su carrera profesional y comprar un automóvil que servirá para uso personal y para llevar productos a las ciudades de Puno y Urubamba. 

El socio se encuentra agradecido por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
18 year-old Cesar is single and currently studying tourism at a private institute called Esitur. He is in his third term. In his free time Cesar helps his parents sell crafts at their stall, a job he’s been doing for the last twelve years. Cesar is going to start a workshop making silverware and then give these crafts to his parents to sell. He says that tourism and sales are not doing very well because of the heavy rains that fell on the city, forcing many tourists to cancel their bookings. Cesar will use the loan to buy silversmithing tools such as a soldering iron, and materials like silver. His greatest wish is complete his professional training and buy a car both for personal use and to transport products to the towns of Puno and Urubamba. He is grateful for this opportunity to obtain a loan and promises to repay it according to the schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy tools

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es:
Julio Cesar M. F.,  Labora como Vigilante en el Teatro Nacional Rubén Darío de Managua, el tiene un hijo a su cargo,  y este  se encuentran en edad escolar, es casado, es su primer  crédito con CEPRODEL y este va hacer invertido en el mejoramiento de su casa de habitación, gracias al financiamiento otorgados por CEPRODEL.  
El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de materiales de construcción  como: cemento, arena y piso para terminar de poner el piso en su casa de habitación.
 Todo esto con el objetivo de Brindarles mayor seguridad y  una mejor condición de vida a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Julio César M. F. works as a guard in Managua's Teatro Nacional Rubén Darío. He has one school-age son and is married. This is first loan from CEPRODEL, and he will invest it in improving his one-room house, thanks to the financing CEPRODEL provides. The requested loan will be used to purchase construction materials like cement, sand, and flooring so he can finish installing the floor in his home. The goal of all this is to offer his son a better, safer living environment.

Translated from Spanish by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improving and expanding his home

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
A dedicated member of Ahon Sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva microfinance partner in the Philippines, since 2006, Luzviminda is grateful for access to the capital that supports her entrepreneurial dreams. Luzviminda has achieved solid performance with her regular attendance to group meetings and her steady repayments. With the support of ASHI and Kiva lenders, Luzviminda is hopeful that the family business will continue to flourish. With continuing success, the business will deliver stable revenue, fund the education of her five children until they finish college, and will support improvements in her family’s quality of life.

To provide additional income for her family, Luzviminda would like to receive a new loan of 30,000PHP to expand the family’s fishing business. With the loan, she will purchase raw materials including fish cages, bamboo, and nets. With this additional equipment, Luzviminda believes their fish inventory will increase thus generating higher income and profits from the business.
 
Luzviminda M. is 50 years old, married and has five children. She lives in the coastal town of Talim Island, Binangonan Rizal with her husband, Severino.  Her husband has been engaged in the fishing business for almost five years. This business supports the family.  

About ASHI: Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI) has the distinction of being the oldest existing replication of Grameen Bank Approach (GBA) to credit delivery to the bottom poor in the Philippines. With its outstanding achievements over the years, it has become one of the role models in credit delivery to the poor in the country.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials including fish cages, bamboo, and nets.

loans.name: Jujeth

texts.en:
Jujeth S. is from the village of Talisayan, Misamis Oriental. She is 32 years old. Jujeth is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Jujeth owns & operates a business venture selling seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Jujeth has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Jujeth joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Jujeth is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Jujeth from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve & expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Laura

texts.en:
Laura J. is from the village of Talisayan, Misamis Ori. She is 35 years old. Laura is married and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Laura owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. Laura has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 1,200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Laura joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Laura is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Laura from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve & expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Vicente

texts.en:
Vicente K. is from the village of Tambagan, Medina Misamis Oriental. He is 38 years old. Vicente is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Vicente owns & operates a transport services business for local community members. Vicente has been a driver of a multi-cab for over 5 years and earns approximately 200 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Vicente joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Vicente is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to expand services provided. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Vicente from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve & expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to expand transport services provided.

loans.name: Elma

texts.en: Elma B. is from the village of Tambagan, Medina, Misamis Oriental. She is 48 years old. Elma is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Elma operates a business venture doing massage services for local community members. Elma has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2009, Elma joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. Elma decided to request a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional materials needed to provide better service. This will be the second loan taken out by Elma from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional materials needed to provide better service

loans.name: Kreum

texts.en:
Mrs. Kreum L. is a 49-year-old farmer. She was married, but divorced her husband when her kids were very young. She has three children who are no longer in school and work. One is a furniture maker, one is a tailor and the other one is a temporary laborer. To pursue a daily revenue, L. has a skill of cooking meals for wedding parties. 

L. will be using her money to buy accessories for her child's furniture-making business.

loans.use: To buy accessories for furniture making

loans.name: Conception

texts.en: Conception A. is from the village of San Miguel, Gingoog City. She is 49 years old. Conception is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Conception runs a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food and daily-use products in the local community. Conception has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 2,500 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2010, Conception joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Conception is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Conception from HSPFI, a Kiva partner. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: San Miguel, Gingoog City, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita S. is from the village of Malinao in Gingoog City. She is 50 years old. Anita is married and has 2 adult children. To make a living, Anita makes and sells snacks and other delicacies in the local community. Anita has been engaged in her business for over 1 years and earn approximately 1,400 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Anita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Anita is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This will be Anita's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Prak

texts.en:
Mr. H., age 60, is a father of five children; three are married and live separately and two are single and help the family work. Mr. H. is married to Pheap, age 40, who works as a local farmer on the land behind her house. 

H. is a local farmer who plants rice and vegetables on the land that he inherited from his parents. H. has a daughter who is jobless. He hopes to encourage her train for a suitable occupation, but he doesn't have cash to make that possible. Thus, he would like to ask a Kiva loan of $500 for his daughter to open a tailoring business.

loans.use: To begin a tailoring business.

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Despite her age of 69 years, Aurora B. is still an energetic and productive woman. After she proved her capacity to manage a business and repay her previous loan, she is now requesting for a much larger amount to use as additional capital for expanding her hog-raising business. 

Aurora very much enjoys the small profit her business has able to make, because it enables her to meet some of the needs of her grandchildren and children. She hopes that her business will grow continuously and have more profits to meet her own needs and sustain her good health.

loans.use: To purchase more hogs/pigs to raise

loans.name: Oyun-Erdene

texts.en:
Oyun-Erdene is 30 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Tosontsengel soum (district) of Zavhan Province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a "ger," which is a yurt or traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent. They have been living in their current home for 2 years. 

Oyun-Erdene makes traditional Mongolian shoes. Oyun-Erdene sells her shoes to customers in in her home soum and neighbour's soum. She sells her shoes for 60,000–100,000 tugrugs, depending on its decoration. Her monthly profit is 80,000- 150,000 tugrugs (~ $55 - $105 USD). 

Oyun-Erdene makes 4-6 pairs of shoes each month. She is a very hard-working and supportive person. The most important thing to her is being able to provide for her children's education. Oyun-Erdene is saving money for her daughter's education. She is requesting a 700,000 tugrug ($500 USD) loan to purchase necessary materials, such as leather, to make traditional Mongolian shoes.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make shoes

loans.name: Pom

texts.en:
Mr. C., 43, lives in the province of Kompong Tom, Cambodia, where he and his wife own and work a plot of land next to their house, growing both rice and vegetables. They can plant the crops twice a year and they were taught this by a grandfather. C. is currently a good father of four children, all whom are single and help with their mother's farm work and are also working in construction.

In the past, C. always hired the neighbor's cow to plow the farmland in order to grow crops. He has been planning to buy a cow but could not due to the family's financial problems. Therefore, he has decided to seek a loan on Kiva to buy a cow to support his farming business. (Mr. C.’s wife appears in the photo.)

loans.use: To buy a cow to support his farming business

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Mr. Meas S. and his wife are local village cultivators. His wife is shown in the photo. Meas S. earns a living growing different kinds of crops on his own farmland, located away from his house. He has eight children: five are married and the others are single. Four of the children are employed at a variety of jobs. Meas S. needs a loan to buy more farming supplies for his business. He is hopeful that he will benefit from higher income following the loan request.

loans.use: To buy more farming supplies for his business.

loans.name: Gloren

texts.en:
From Gloren T.’s various income generating activities, financed by the loan she received from ASHI, she has been able to have her own income. This has been a great benefit to her family’s basic needs, especially towards the educational needs of her children. Though it was hard for her to sustain three kinds of businesses (hog fattening, fish and rice selling), she has greatly enjoyed discovering her own capacity for managing her small finances.

With the support of her loving husband, Gloren now is requesting, from Kiva, another loan to be able to support the financial needs of her growing businesses. She hopes that once she has made it grow, she will also be able to increases her profits. This is her means to overcome poverty.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for fattening, rice and fish for selling.

loans.name: Merlie's Group

texts.en:
Merlie R. owns and operates a motorcycle transport business providing service to her community. She is 27 years old, married and has one school-age child. They are from the town of Gud, San Isidro. Merlie has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2009, Merlie joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Merlie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. She is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This will be her second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. 

Merlie is the leader of a ten member group accessing a loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members, if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is "Merlie R. Group".

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Aura Aurora

texts.es:
La Señora Aura Aurora Mejia, es originaria del Municipio de San Francisco del Norte, comarca La Rastra, ha tenido 2 créditos, es una excelente cliente, los ha pagado en tiempo y forma con sus abonos mensuales, solicita un crédito para mejorar su negocio, para compra de cosméticos, ropa para niños, jóvenes, tales como: camisas, pantalones y cosméticos.
Le ha servido mucho ya que gracias al crédito su familia ha salido adelante y vive dignamente.
texts.en:
Ms. Aura Aurora Mejia, from the city of San Francisco del Norte, La Rasta region, has had 2 loans. She is an excellent client and she paid her loans and repayments back on time. She is requesting a loan in order to improve her business to buy cosmetics, children’s and teen’s clothing like: shirts, pants. Thanks to the loan her family has moved forward and they live with dignity.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Jackson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy clothing for children and young people, cosmetics

loans.name: Dinia

texts.en: Dinia E. is a 56 year-old industrious woman. Both she and her husband run a small business as a source of income to support the needs of their family. It was Dinia’s loan, received from ASHI previously, that has enabled her to start up her own hog/pig fattening business and to support her husband’s sales (various goods from the community) business. They both enjoy running their own business and have been able to pay back the full loan they received from ASHI. Now, they hope that the larger amount of loan they are requesting to Kiva through ASHI will be granted for them to have the opportunity to grow their businesses. They hope to increase their profits in order to continuously support their needs. They dream of having a better kind of life – a life that is not under the umbrella of poverty.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for fattening and raising.

loans.name: Svay

texts.en: Mrs. C. is a domestic trader, 48-years-old, who lives with her own medium family in Kompong Tom Province. Her husband is 49-year-old Teang. He assists her in the business. This couple has six children: four are married and the other two are single. All of the children are no longer in school; they work in different jobs. To look for daily revenue, C. buys products such as potatoes, rice, and salt in bulk to sell. She also stores her items for a while at her home and will resell them to buyers when the prices come to the highest. C. is applying for a loan to buy a motorcycle so she can buy the items more quickly.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria B. is from the town of Poblacion East, Sta. Ignacia, Tarlac. She is 35 years old. Gloria is married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Gloria owns & operates a business selling fish balls and other dim sum to the local community. Gloria has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Gloria joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gloria is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Gloria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Generose

texts.en: Generose D. plans to sell fish for her small business. The loan she is requesting from Kiva presently will be used to purchase fish, which she will directly sell to people around their village. She hopes that through the profits that this business will be making she will be able to support the needs of her four children, ages ranging from three to 11 years old. She also hopes that her husband would support her in her own business ventures so that she will find the success she has been looking for, after having been several types of businesses already. Generose also thinks that she will be successful with this one and she will never stop doing business and find the one that will bring her and her family out of poverty someday.

loans.use: To purchase fish for selling.

loans.name: Yonn

texts.en:
The village woman in the photograph is C., age 27. She lives in the province of Kompong Tom, which is the best territory for farming. C. is a married woman who is devoted to her young child, who attends school and depends on her care. She has a small trade selling farming products in bulk. Also, she buys products from farmers to store in her home for a while before selling. Her husband assists her in the business. In addition, the family always takes time to plant rice when the farming season comes. 

C. is taking out her loan to buy a cow to use in the farming business.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Nasroding

texts.en:
Nasroding D. is from the village of  Talakag Bukidnon. She is 22 years old. Nasroding is single. To make a living, Nasroding owns & operates a specialized retail store selling personal products such body powder, baby oil, clips, watches and more in the local community. Nasroding has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nasroding joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Nasroding has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Nasroding is requesting a new loan of 8000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Nasroding from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve & expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Vuth

texts.en: Mrs. Vuth M. is 39 years of age and lives along the river in Siem Reap. Vuth M. and her husband are currently local fishermen. They depend on catching fish in and around Tunle Sap Lake. That is the main place where the fish shelter. They have been fishing for a long time and earn at least $5 per day. This income is used to cover the family's living expenses and especially to make sure the five children get the highest education. Vuth M. is applying for a loan in order to buy more traps and nets for fishing.

loans.use: To buy more traps and nets

loans.name: Vicente

texts.en:
Vicente P. is from the town of Poblacion East, Sta. Ignacia, Tarlac. He is 36 years old. Vicente is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Vicente owns & operates a business selling seasonal fruits in the market. Vicente has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Vicente joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Vicente is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Vicente from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Aurora

texts.en:
Aurora F. is from the town of Poblacion East, Sta. Ignacia Tarlac. She is 46 years old. Aurora is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Aurora owns & operates a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Aurora has been engaged in her business for over 14 years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Aurora joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Aurora is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Aurora from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Chum

texts.en: To make a more comfortable settlement, Mrs. S., age 41, grows a variety of crops on her own farmland that she inherited from her grandparents. Also, she relies on the income from her husband, who works driving a trailer-motor taxi around the community. This humble couple has five children, who are going to school and dependent on them. Recently S.’s husband can’t generate much income because his taxi is often broken. To solve the problem, S. sought a loan for her husband to replace his broken taxi.

loans.use: To replace her husband's broken taxi

loans.name: Angelita

texts.en:
Despite Angelita B. not being able to graduate her two eldest children from college, she still works hard to be able to send the rest of her seven children to a higher level of education. If she can’t graduate all of them from college, at least she can support them so they become good citizens of the country. Although she sometimes feels sad seeing her family’s poor situation and her eldest child with her husband working hard, farming rice for other people for a small amount of money, she can still pretend that she is happy, especially in front of her children. Her children are aged from 8 to 22. 

Angelita has become hopeful since she became a member of ASHI. Through ASHI products and services, especially loans which can be accessed by the members, she hopes to change her family’s standard of living. Now she is excited about the loan she is requesting through Kiva (ASHI partner) because she can start her own small businesses which are hog/pig fattening and rice selling. She hopes that one day her businesses will grow and she will be able to realize her dreams.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for fattening and rice for selling.

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.en:
Rodolfo J. Jr. is from the village of Sitio Bungil Sapang Maragol, Tarlac. He is 36 years old. Rodolfo is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Rodolfo owns & operates a business providing dress making services to local community members. Rodolfo has been engaged in his business for over three years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rodolfo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rodolfo is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fabric & materials. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rodolfo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics & materials

loans.name: Edgardo

texts.en:
Edgardo N. is from the city of Calingcuan, Tarlac. He is 39 years old. Edgardo is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Edgardo owns & operates a business a food stall. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from tending a canteen in the community. Edgardo has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Edgardo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Edgardo is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Edgardo from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Leonard

texts.en:
Leonard Q. is from the village of Talakag Bukidnon. He is 31 years old. Leonard is married and has 3 school-aged children. Leonard owns & operates a business providing trisikad (a motorized tricycle) transportation to local community members. Leonard has been working in his business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Leonard joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. Leonard is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding his business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Leonard from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Nhen's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. S., 61, has three children. She has been selling noodles and soft drinks in the local busy market since 2000 and earns approximately $3.00 per day. Her husband, Mr. Thon, 66, assists her in the business. S. is requesting a loan to decorate her noodle shop so she can attract more customers. 


S. leads a group of four other women:
1. Mrs. P. is a fruit seller. In order to improve her business, she is requesting a loan to increase her working capital.
2. Mrs. N. is a grocery seller who is asking for a loan to assist her business.
3. Mrs. L. is a local tailor and needs a loan to buy more clothing for sewing.
4. Mrs. P. sells a few cooking ingredients and she would like to ask for a loan to expand her inventory.

loans.use: To decorate her noodle shop.

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn C. is a 42-year-old woman who remained strong despite so many challenges she went through being poor. She has ventured into several kinds of livelihood activities to have her own income to augment her husband’s small and sporadic income being a hired farm laborer. However, because of the large amount of expenses her family incurs, especially her 10 children whose age range is from two to 23 years old, her income would not be enough to cover everything, including the sustainability of her small business. Despite that, Jocelyn wouldn’t want to stop dreaming and hoping that their lives would change someday. Therefore, she joined ASHI, the first Kiva field partner in the Philippines, in order to request a loan, which will be used to start her own business. Having the opportunity that ASHI is giving her (especially access to loans), she is optimistic that she will be able to have a source of capital to finance the needs of her hog/pig fattening business. Her fattened animals will be sold either slaughtered or alive to people around their village or to meat vendors in the public market. 

For Jocelyn, there is no reason to give up the fight against poverty because her children are innocent about dealing with it; thus, she and her husband have to do it for them. As much as possible, she really wants to offer them a life that is enjoyable and worth living for.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for fattening.

loans.name: Toan

texts.en: Mrs. T. has been married for about three years to Mr. Choun and they are blessed with two young kids who are not enrolled in school. T., 23, has been selling fresh fish since 2005 in the busy local market, earning approximately $3 each day. In addition, her husband works as a temporary laborer in the construction field. In order to generate extra profit and make business more successful, T. is applying for a loan to use as capital to improve her business financially.

loans.use: To improve her business

loans.name: Ravshan

texts.ru: Тошбоев Равшан проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 42 года. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Занимается животноводством. Разводит крупно- рогатый скот для перепродажи их на мяса. В этой области более 5 лет. Кроме того развитие данного сектора позволяет обеспечивать рынки свежим мясом. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Ravshan T. lives in the Yavan district. He is 42 years old, married and has 5 children. He is involved in animal husbandry and breeds cattle to be resold for meat. Ravshan has been involved in this field for over 5 years. Besides, the development of this business sector allows to provide fresh meat to the markets. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of cattle.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Holmahmad

texts.ru: Саидов Холмахмад проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 36 лет. Женат, имеет 6 детей. Жена, домохазяйка. Сам Холмахмад имеет среднее образование. Зарабатывает путем разведения скота. Он создал все условия для продвижения своего бизнеса. Покупает молодых бычков, откармливает и продает на рынке по более выгодной цене. В этой области более 5 лет. Кроме того занимается строительными работами по найму. Кредит берет для закупа крупно- рогатого скота.
texts.en:
Holmahmad S. lives in the Yavan district. He is 36 years old, married and has 6 children. His wife is a homemaker. Holmahmad has a secondary education and earns a living by breeding livestock. He created all of the necessary conditions for moving his business forward. He buys young bulls, fattens and resells them at the market at a more profitable price. Holmahmad has been in this business for over 5 years. Besides this, he is also involved in construction work for-hire. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of cattle.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of cattle

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida A. is from the city of Baras-Baras, Tarlac. She is 41 and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, she has a business selling rice in the local community. Zenaida has had this business for over two years and earns approximately 12,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Zenaida is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Zenaida from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Isuf

texts.ru: Кенджаев Исуф проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 51 год. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Образование среднее. Занимается растениеводством. Опыт в этой сфере более 15 лет. При доме имеет небольшой участок земли, где выращивает овощи для семьи и продажи на рынке. Кредит берет для покупки семян и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Isuf K. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 51 years old, married and has 4 children. He has a secondary education and is involved in agriculture. Isuf has 15 years of experience in this field. He has a small plot of land by his house, where he grows vegetables for this family and for sale at the market. He is requesting a loan for the purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Marlyn

texts.en:
Marlyn G. is an industrious woman who is requesting a loan from Kiva through ASHI. This is for additional capital for growing her current cattle and hog/pig fattening business using her previous loan received from ASHI. Now that she has proven her capacity to pay back the full amount of the previous loan and her business has brought happiness to her and her family, she aims to make it profitable and sustainable as a source of financial support to sustain the education of her children until they graduate from college and their lives are changed.  

Being a mother to her 10 children, Marlyn has no other wish but for them to experience life not just being poor.  For now, she knows she has a lot of challenges to face in order to achieve her dreams, especially for her one special child.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for fattening.

loans.name: Mumin

texts.ru: Бердиев Мумин проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 55 лет. Женат, имеет 8 детей. Образование высшее "Агроном". Более 18 лет занимается растениеводством. Имеет участок земли, где выращивает оващи. Кредит берет для закупа минеральных удобрений. Он хочет получить хороший урожай для продажи.
texts.en:
Mumin B. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 55 years old, married and has 8 children. He has a higher education as an agronomist. Mumin has been involved in agriculture for over 18 years. He has a plot of land, where he grows vegetables. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of mineral fertilizers. Mumin wants to obtain a good harvest for sale.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of mineral fertilizers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Muhammadjon

texts.ru: Юсупов Мухаммаджон проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 38 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Мухаммаджон более 10 лет занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет земельный участок, где сажает арбуз. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений. Мухаммаджон хочет посеить и получить хороший урожай для продажи.
texts.en:
Muhammadjon Y. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 38 years old, married and has 5 children. His wife is a homemaker. Muhammadjon has been involved in agriculture for over 10 years. He has a plot of land by his house, where he grows watermelons. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers. Muhammadjon wants to sow and get a good harvest for sale.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Mema Group

texts.en:
Rehema W., age 26, is single. She has a grocery and a retail shop, which she started two years ago.  She works from 6am to 11pm and she is able to make a monthly profit of about $148.

This will be Rehema’s second motisha loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. (A motisha loan is a loan product offered by Tujijenge that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended.) She used the previous loan to increase her business stock and she has paid back the loan successfully. She hopes for a new loan to improve her grocery and retail shop stock.

Rehema will share this loan with her subgroup, Mema Group, which totals six members.  The members of the group will hold each other accountable in paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Rehema is the only woman.

loans.use: To increase her grocery stock

loans.name: Otgontsetseg

texts.en: Otgontsetseg is 52 years old and lives with her sibling and sibling's child in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Otgontsetseg's sibling works as a security guard at a private company and her sibling's child is a secondary school student. Otgontsetseg presently operates a handicraft and knitting business in her town. Other than knitted crafts, she makes a variety of products using decorative beads. Otgontsetseg has operated her business since 2008 and has made quick progress. She is a very forward thinking and creative woman. She is a graduate of the College of Finance and Economics and had a long career as an accountant with a telecommunication company. She started her handicrafts business when her job was cut by the company. In 2009, Otgontsetseg established a non-governmental organization called Anirguin Chimee. Its members consist of other handicraft makers. Otgontsetseg hopes to broaden her organization's activities, organize training for disabled people and create a workplace for them in the future. Otgontsetseg is a very hardworking person, and says, “I would like to purchase my own counter at which to sell my products.” She is requesting a 400,000-tugrug loan to increase her working capital and purchase necessary materials such as thread and beads for her business.

loans.use: To purchase materials such as thread and beads for her business

loans.name: Riziki Group

texts.en:
Silvia R., age 38, is married with three children, ages 19, 16 and 5. She has a grocery, which she started seven years ago. She works from 8 a.m. to after midnight daily and she is able to make a monthly profit of about $202.

This will be Silvia’s second loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, a Kiva partner. She used the previous loan to start a local chicken business and she has paid back the loan successfully. She hopes for a new loan to improve on the grocery stock.

Silvia will share this loan with her subgroup, called Riziki Group, which totals seven members. These members deal in selling telephones, fruits, vegetables, eggs, blocks and have shops. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back the loan. 

In the picture, Silvia is in a red dress.

loans.use: To increase grocery stock

loans.name: Nuriddin

texts.ru: Хайдаров Нуриддин проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 27 лет. Женат, имеет 2 детей. Образование среднее. Основным источником дохода его семьи является растениеводство. Он берет землю в аренду, засеивает кортофелем. После того как получает урожай, продает на рынке. Занимается этим видом деятельности уже 6 лет. Сейчас посевной сезон и Нуриддин хочет посеить дыню и арбуз. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений.
texts.en:
Nuriddin H. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 27 years old, married and has 2 children. He has a secondary education. Agriculture is the primary source of income for his family. Nuriddin leases the land and plants potatoes. After he receives the harvest, he sells it at a market. He has been involved in this business for 6 years. Now is the sowing season, and Nuriddin wants to plant honeydew and watermelon. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Javzandulam

texts.en:
Javzandulam is 44 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in the Uvurhangai province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a house, which they own. They have been living together in their current home for four years. 

Presently, Javzandulam operates a mobile meat-trading business. She purchases meat at wholesale prices from meat sellers and resells the meat for a profit in Uyanga soum (district). During the winter, Javzandulam sells meat, but for the summer she sells livestock for meat to her customers. 

Over the years, she has gained great experience and has steadily expanded her business. Javzandulam has a great business mind and her business is very important to her. She says, “I would like to expand my business and to create my own workplace.” 

She is requesting a 1,500,000 tugrug loan to purchase more meat at wholesales prices to resell at a profit.

loans.use: To purchase more meat

loans.name: Joseca

texts.en:
Joseca R., 27 years of age, wants to have her own business to manage and grow and to be able have her own profit to augment her husband’s small income as a fisherman. This is so because the way she perceives life now is different from the way she did when she was still single. Now she always has to consider her husband and two children (eight and nine years old) in her decision-making and plans because she owns the responsibility of giving them a better life in the future. 

When Joseca decided to request another loan from ASHI, which will be used as an additional capital to grow her hog fattening, rice and fish selling businesses, her husband’s opinion was asked. His support inspired her to pursue her plans for the business until it becomes profitable and sustainable.

loans.use: To purchase piglets for fattening, rice and fish for selling.

loans.name: Maryel

texts.en:
Maryel C. is from the village of San Isidro, La Paz, Tarlac. She is 20 years old and married with one small child. To make a living, Maryel has a store selling DVDs (disks). She has been in this business for over a year and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month. 

In 2010, Maryel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maryel is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Maryel from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory and for working capital

loans.name: Maria Concepcion

texts.en:
Maria Concepcion D. C. is from the village of Caggay, Tuguegarao City. She is 38 years old and single.To make a living, Maria Concepcion runs a food stall near the school. She is relatively new to this business.

In 2009, Maria Concepcion joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maria Concepcion has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI and is now requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Maria Concepcion from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Dorcas Charo

texts.en:
Dorcas is a 28-year-old woman married to Ronald. She lives in Kibokoni-Malindi where she targets her customers from Malindi. She is a tailor and she has had a tailoring business for the last seven years. Dorcas, who also does some hairdressing on the side, earns a monthly profit of Kshs 17,800. 

Dorcas, who has her first loan, was introduced to Kadet by the group's secretary. She plans to spend the Kshs 10,000 to buy material (for making clothes) for her customers so that they don't have to source them from other places. She plans to utilize the extra income from this loan to build rentals on her plot and to provide piped water to her family.

A hardworking woman, Dorcas hopes to develop the rental houses on her plot fully with water and electricity.

loans.use: To purchase materials for tailoring

loans.name: Bum-Ayush

texts.en: Bum-Ayush B. is 40 years old and lives with his wife and son in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. His wife operates a sewing business and makes traditional Mongolian clothing. During the day, Bum-Ayush operates a taxi service in his home province. He has been operating a taxi service since 2008, and has steadily grown the business. Originally, he had been a herder in the countryside with a few heads of livestock. Currently, Bum-Ayush has a loyal customer base due to his good service and communication skills.  His average monthly sales revenue is 450,000 tugrugs (~ 316 USD) and profit is 250,000 tugrugs (~ 175 USD). Besides his business, Bum-Ayush also helps his wife's sewing business. His wife, Tserenhand, makes traditional Mongolian clothing and earns 80,000 tugrugs (~ 56 USD) per month. She has been operating this business since 2000, and has become an experienced sewer. Bum-Ayush and his wife work hard to improve their quality of life. He is requesting a 600,000-tugrug loan to purchase spare parts for his car for his taxi service business.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts

loans.name: Kyebajja Tobona General Traders Group, Jinja

texts.en:
M. Ziita, shown at the top left in the small photo is the leader of her lending group although she does not appear in the big group photo.

M. Ziita is an enterprising 47-year-old, married local-brew seller. Like many others, her future plan is to build herself a permanent house and fully provide for all her children’s educational needs. She has six children under her care, with only one attending school.

Being a hardworking woman, Ziita thinks she can establish a business niche for herself in the course of time, with some support rendered to her. She highlights the ever-changing preference for other drinks by her customers as a major setback. This, at times, leaves her with no serious customers at all on some days.

Ziita operates her business from Masese in Jinja and she belongs to the Kyebajja Tobona General Traders’ Group. Her business generates profits of 300,000 Ugandan shillings per month and she cites the good quality of her brew and her good customer care skills as her vantage point.

With a loan of 450,000 shillings she anticipates making substantial strides in her business by buying more raw materials like bananas and yeast for better productivity.

loans.use: To buy raw materials like bananas and yeast for making local brew

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou L. is from the city of Matatalaib, Tarlac. She is 29 years old and married with one infant child. To make a living, Marilou owns a specialized retail store where she sells mobile phone credits. Marilou has been in business over 2 years and earns approximately 8500 PHP monthly.  Marilou has recently joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Marilou is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to expand her business.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand her mobile phone business.

loans.name: Shavkat

texts.ru: Хайдаров Шавкат проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 29 лет. Женат, имеет одного ребёнка. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Шавкат имеет среднее образование. Более 8 лет занимается растениеводством. Он берет землю в аренду, засеивает пшеницей и кортофелем. После того как получает урожай продает на рынке. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений. Шавкат хочет посеить и получить хороший урожай для продажи.
texts.en:
Shavkat H. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 29 years old, married and has one child. His wife is a homemaker. Shavkat has a secondary education and has been involved in agriculture for over 8 years. He leases land and plants wheat and potatoes. He then sells the harvest at the market. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers. Shavkat wants to sow and get a good harvest for sale.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda P. is from the village of Santa Ines East, Santa Ignacia, Tarlac. She is 42 years old and married with an adult child. To make a living, Erlinda runs a general store selling a variety of different products in the local community. Erlinda has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Erlinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Erlinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7000 PHP from ASKI which she used to to purchase additional products to sell. Erlinda is requesting her second loan, for 8000 PHP, in order to purchase new items and expand her product offering.

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To expand the product offering in her general store.

location.town: Sta. Ines East,  Sta. Ignacia, Tarlac

loans.name: Kwentola Group, Jinja

texts.en:
W. Michael is shown in the small photo at the top left and also appears in the big group photo. He belongs to the Kwentola Group based in Jinja.

Michael has been making minimal ends meet for the last five years riding a commercial local transport motorcycle, commonly known as boda-boda (a motorcycle fitted with a tailor-made seat over the rear wheel for transporting people). Before he began plying this trade, 37-year-old Michael worked in Kengrow industries (a local company). With his saved earnings, he was able to buy himself a motorbike.

Michael is a married man with two children aged 8 and 5, both in primary school. He hopes to educate them up to university level if his business circumstances improve.

According to Michael’s recollection, since he took root in this business, many drawbacks have plagued him. On many occasions, he, like many of his other motorbike riding colleagues, has had to bear the brunt of robberies.

At his police barracks stage, in Jinja town, Michael’s main customer calling card is his friendliness and reliability. On a weekly basis, he reveals, he probably makes 60,000 Ugandan shillings, and for that reason, he is a man with a mission to elevate his status.

Michael strongly carries conviction that a loan of 250,000 Ugandan shillings will go a long way in rendering him support. His future plans include buying himself another motorbike and consequently expanding his finances. He is a man who is very passionate about educating his children and, with this loan, he thinks he will be able to see to it that his two kids get a good quality education.

loans.use: To pay school fees for his two children

loans.name: Shiirev

texts.en:
For the past five years Shiirev, 38, has been living with his wife and daughter in a ger, a traditional Mongolian nomadic housing tent, in Uvurhangai Province, Mongolia. Purchasing the necessary machinery parts and raw materials from Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia, Shiirev has operated an auto repair business since 2005 and has steadily expanded his business as more and more people have bought cars in Mongolia in recent years, Previously, he operated a transportation business between Ulaanbaatar and Uvurhangai Province with his own car. His wife Tuya has been operating a hairdressing business since 2000, and also helps Shiirev's auto repair business.

Shiirev is a very hard-working person with a great business mind. He says, “I would like to expand my business and open a larger auto repair center.” He is now requesting a 3,500,000 tugrugs (~ 2450 USD) loan to purchase machinery parts at wholesale prices for his business.

loans.use: To purchase machinery parts

loans.name: Bahaa

texts.en: Bahaa is a 28-year-old married man from Nablus who lives with his wife and four children, one of whom has recently entered school. Formerly working with his brother in cosmetics, Bahaa eventually decided that he would like to work on his own. After he took leadership training which taught him how to be independent and responsible, he opened his own barbershop in 2002.  Bahaa hopes through this loan to buy a skin-cleaning machine which will bring him more customers, and he aspires to open a barbershop near AlNajah Academy in the future.

loans.use: To buy a skin-cleaning machine which will bring him more customers

loans.name: Genesia Jacob Group

texts.en:
Genesia J., from the village of Poblacion, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental, is the 48-year-old leader of a five-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Genesia, who is married and has four grown children, owns and operates a general store that sells a variety of products in the local community. Engaged in her business for over five years, she earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Genesia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 9000 PHP from PMPC that was used to purchase additional products to sell, Genesia is requesting a new loan, her fifth, of 10000 PHP to purchase new items to expand product offering. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering
